Award.AbstractNarration:
Problems involving the approximation and representation of data taken from scattered sites in space, from surfaces, or from more complicated structures arise in diverse scientific fields. Kernel methods are valued for their ability to treat such unstructured data. They are also important examples of meshless methods, computational tools that function successfully without the need of accompanying structures like grids or triangulations. The principal investigator plans to study analytic and computational properties of scalable localized bases (a powerful new methodology for working with kernels) and to use these bases to address some fundamental challenges in kernel based approximation. The investigator expects to generate algorithms that will be of use to scientists and engineers who work with unstructured data and large-scale datasets. Throughout the project, the investigator will mentor graduate students by involving them in both the theoretical and the applied aspects of this research.

Unlike other computational tools (like wavelets, splines and piecewise polynomial finite elements), kernel methods do not explicitly involve a scaling operation: as data becomes more dense, the kernel is not required to be dilated. This allows kernels to produce approximates from complex geometrical configurations where a single scale is not apparent. However, it often leads to problems involving large, poorly conditioned linear systems, the solution of which is both slow and unstable. It has been demonstrated that in many cases the underlying function spaces possess stable, highly localized bases that can be constructed rapidly. There is compelling evidence that near linear processing of many computational problems is possible, and fast algorithms may exist to treat many of the basic operations involving kernels. The proposed research seeks to generate scalable bases in new settings (i.e., for new kernels and on new manifolds), to understand and overcome fundamental problems stemming from boundary effects and highly non-uniform arrangements of data, and ultimately to implement parallelized, fast algorithms for kernel approximation with these bases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Problems involving the approximation and representation of data taken from scattered sites in space, from surfaces, or from more complicated structures arise in diverse scientific fields. Kernel methods are valued for their ability to treat such unstructured data. They are also important examples of meshless methods, computational tools that function successfully without the need of accompanying structures like grids or triangulations.

Unlike other computational tools (like wavelets, splines and piecewise polynomial finite elements), kernel methods do not explicitly involve a scaling operation: as data becomes more dense, the kernel is not required to be dilated. This allows kernels to produce approximates from complex geometrical configurations where a single scale is not apparent. However, it often leads to problems involving large, poorly conditioned linear systems, the solution of which is both slow and unstable.

It has been demonstrated that in some cases (namely, for some problems on the sphere) the underlying kernel spaces possess stable, highly localized bases (called scalable bases) that can be constructed rapidly. In many instances, scalable bases can accelerate and stabilize the large, poorly conditioned computational problems emerging in meshless methods. During the funding period, the principal investigator studied analytic and computational properties of scalable bases and used these techniques to address some fundamental challenges in kernel based approximation.

One aspect of the project was to develop algorithms which construct such bases in general settings (beyond the narrow example of the sphere). Such constructions have now been demonstrated by the PI and collaborators for certain families of kernels on very general Euclidean domains, and many non-Euclidean structures. The construction is both efficient (having nearly linear computational complexity in terms of the dimension of the underlying kernel space) and highly parallelizable.

With collaborators, he was able to demonstrate the first Bernstein (inverse) estimates for spaces generated by kernels over domains with boundaries. Bernstein estimates comprise one of the two fundamental types of inequality used in approximation theory (in conjunction with Jackson, or direct, estimates) and often play a key role in numerical methods for PDEs. They have been conspicuously absent from kernel approximation, establishing them for domains with boundaries has been considered a challenging, but important problem.

Another objective was to understand the role played by the boundary in kernel approximation -- for almost two decades it has been well-known that  convergence rates for kernel approximation are sharply curtailed when approximation takes place over a region with a boundary. This phenomenon is known as the "boundary effects" for kernel approximation. The PI has given a precise analysis of these effects and developed an approximation method that overcomes the boundary effects by carefully oversampling near to the boundary. 

In addition to supporting travel (both for the PI, but also for bringing collaborators to Hawaii), the investigator supported and mentored graduate students by involving them in both the theoretical and the applied aspects of this research.
